facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1564 of 1968 was filed under section 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1564 of 1968. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated May 23, 1968-of the Allahabad High Court in Election Petition No. 40 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated May 23, 1968 of Allahabad High Court in Election Petition No. 40 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1564 of 1968. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated May 23, 1968-of the Allahabad High Court in Election Petition No. 40 of 1967. Danial Latifi, S. J. Hyder, Rajindra Singh and M. I. Khowaja, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant challenged the election of the respondent to the U.P. Legislative Assembly from Iglas Constituency in the general election held in February 1967.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal under s. 116A of the Representation, of the People Act, 1951 arises from the decision in Election Petition No. 40 of 1967 on the file of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad. In that petition the appellant challenged the election of the respondent to the U.P. Legislative Assembly from Iglas Constituency in the general election held in February 1967.

facts.text: Respondent secured 10,705 votes more than the appellant in the election.

anchor.surface_text: In that election the appellant, the respondent and four others companytested. The respondent secured 10,705 votes more than the appellant. Other candidates secured less votes than the appellant.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the election petition. Against that order the appellant has companye up in appeal.

facts.text: Respondent raised preliminary objection that the petition was not maintainable as it was not properly presented.

anchor.surface_text: Before going into the merits of the appeal, it is necessary to deal with the preliminary objections to the appeal, taken by the respondent. The first objection taken was that the petition was number maintainable as it was number properly presented.

facts.text: Respondent objected that the petition ceased to be maintainable due to dissolution of U.P. Legislative Assembly by President's Proclamation on April 15, 1968 under Article 356.

anchor.surface_text: The second objection was that the petition ceased to be maintainable as a result of the dissolution of the U.P. Legislative Assembly as per the Presidents Proclamation of April 15, 1968 under Art. 356 1  of the Constitution. That Proclamation was issued during the pendency of this election petition before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court found that the election petition was presented to the registry by an advocate's clerk in the immediate presence of the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found as a fact that the election petition was presented to the registry by an advocates clerk in the immediate presence of the petitioner. Therefore, in substance though number in form, it was presented by the petitioner himself.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the election petition did not abate due to dissolution of the assembly.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the companytention of Mr. Veda Vyasa, learned Counsel for the respondent that the petition must be held to have become infructuous in view of the dissolution of the assembly.

facts.text: Appellant challenged election on various grounds, most given up in trial court or Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the election of the respondent on various grounds, most of which were given up either in the trial companyrt or in this Court.

facts.text: Only issues Nos. 7, 8 and 10 remain in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: At present we are companycerned only with issues Nos. 7, 8 and 10.

facts.text: Issue No. 7: Whether Exh. 7 was got printed and published by the respondent. Court found no satisfactory evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The only question arising under issue No. 7 is whether Exh. 7, was got printed and published by the respondent. So far as the question of getting it prepared and printed is companycerned, the evidence principally relied on is that of W. 16 Mohan Singh.

facts.text: High Court and Supreme Court found Mohan Singh (P.W.16) unreliable witness.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that Mohan Singh is a wholly unreliable witness.

facts.text: Issue No. 8 concerns hiring of vehicles: Truck No. USK 503, Bus No. RJL 9729, and a Tractor for conveying voters.

anchor.surface_text: Now companying to issue No. 8 which relates to the companyplaint of the appellant that the respondent, his agents and workers had hired several vehicles for companyveyance of the voters to and from the polling stations.

facts.text: Evidence regarding Truck USK 503 rejected as P.W.45 Sukhbir Singh's evidence false; no such truck union in Hathras.

anchor.surface_text: So far as Truck No. USK 503 is companycerned, the witnesses. who were examined are P.Ws. 37, 40, 41, 45 and 48. Among them the most important witness is P.W. 45 Sukhbir Singh.

facts.text: Evidence regarding Bus RJL 9729 owned by Babu Lal of Jaipur rejected as unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: Now companying to the hiring of Bus RJL 9729, according to the petition that bus was owned by one Babu Lal of Jaipur.

facts.text: Evidence regarding tractor rejected as vague and unconvincing.

anchor.surface_text: Now companying to the tractor, its registration No. was number spoken to by any witness. There is numberevidence about its hiring.

facts.text: Issue No. 10: Election expenses of respondent exceeded prescribed limit. Evidence rejected.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to issue No. 10 which relates to the companyplaint of the appellant that the election expenses incurred by the respondent had exceeded the prescribed limit.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: U.P. Legislative Assembly dissolved by President's Proclamation on April 15, 1968 under Article 356 during pendency of election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The second objection was that the petition ceased to be maintainable as a result of the dissolution of the U.P. Legislative Assembly as per the Presidents Proclamation of April 15, 1968 under Art. 356 1  of the Constitution. That Proclamation was issued during the pendency of this election petition before the High Court.

facts.text: Five candidates contested besides appellant and respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In that election the appellant, the respondent and four others companytested.

facts.text: Appellant filed third election petition; has considerable experience.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant  1  1968 3S.C.R 102. has companysiderable experience of filing election petitions. This was. the third election petition filed by him.

facts.text: High Court rejected evidence of witnesses claiming respondent distributed Exh. 7 pamphlets.

anchor.surface_text: Large number of witnesses were examined to show that either respondent himself distributed pamphlets like Exh. 7 or he got them distributed through others. Their evidence has been companysidered by the High Court in detail and rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court assessment of evidence and defers to High Court's findings on facts.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the High Court has companyrectly assessed, that evidence. Generally, this Court accepts the findings of fact arrived at by the High Court.
Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated May 23, 1968-of the Allahabad High Court

arguments.claim: Election petition presented in substance by petitioner himself though by clerk.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found as a fact that the election petition was presented to the registry by an advocates clerk in the immediate presence of the petitioner. Therefore, in substance though number in form, it was presented by the petitioner himself.

arguments.qualifiers: in substance though number in form

arguments.claim: Purity of elections fundamental; petition continues despite dissolution to punish corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: The purity of elections is of utmost importance in a democratic set-up. No one can be allowed to corrupt the course of an election and get away with it either by resigning his membership or because of the fortuitous circumstance of the assembly having been dissolved.

arguments.claim: RPA statutorily regulates election petitions exhaustively; no abatement on dissolution as not provided.

anchor.surface_text: The election petitions in this country are solely regulated by statutory provisions. Hence unless it is shown that some statutory provision directly or by necessary implication prescribes that the pending election petitions stand abated because of the dissolution of the Assembly, the contention of the respondent cannot be accepted.

arguments.claim: Election petition abates only on death of petitioner per s.112; Chapter IV exhaustive.

anchor.surface_text: Section 112 says An election petition shall abate only on the death of a sole petitioner or of the survivor of several petitioners. ... The law relating to withdrawal and abatement of election petitions is exhaustively dealt with in Chapter IV of Part VI of the Act.

arguments.claim: Election contest is between constituency and candidate; not controlled solely by petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: From the above provisions it is seen that in an election petition, the contest is really between the constituency on the one side and the person or persons complained of on the other. Once the machinery of the Act is moved by a candidate or an elector, the carriage of the case does number entirely rest with the petitioner.

arguments.claim: Defer to High Court findings of fact as they observed witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the High Court has correctly assessed, that evidence. Generally, this Court accepts the findings of fact arrived at by the High Court. Election petitions are tried by experienced judges of the High Court.

holdings.text: The election petition was presented to the registry by an advocate's clerk in the immediate presence of the petitioner. Therefore, in substance though not in form, it was presented by the petitioner himself. Hence the requirement of the law was fully satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found as a fact that the election petition was presented to the registry by an advocates clerk in the immediate presence of the petitioner. Therefore, in substance though number in form, it

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court fact finding accepted; presentation in substance by petitioner satisfies Section 81 RPA.

holdings.text: The election petition does not abate or become infructuous due to dissolution of the U.P. Legislative Assembly under Article 356; High Court was right that it had not abated.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention of Mr. Veda Vyasa, learned Counsel for the respondent that the petition must be held to have become infructuous in view of the dissolution of the assembly. In this

holdings.reasoning_summary: RPA Chapter IV exhaustively deals with abatement (only on death per s.112); no provision for abatement on dissolution; purity of elections requires continuation; contest is constituency vs candidate; English precedent (Carter v Mills) inapplicable.

holdings.text: Exh. 7 was not got printed and published by the respondent; no satisfactory evidence proved the corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: At present we are concerned only with issues Nos. 7, 8 and 10. The only question arising under issue No. 7 is whether Exh. 7, was got printed and published by the respondent. So far as the question

holdings.reasoning_summary: PW16 Mohan Singh unreliable; no link from D-23 voucher; Exh.3 unreliable; distribution witnesses rejected; High Court correctly assessed evidence.

holdings.text: Respondent, agents or workers did not hire vehicles (Truck USK 503, Bus RJL 9729, Tractor) for conveyance of voters; evidence rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the High Court has correctly assessed, that evidence. Generally, this Court accepts the findings of fact arrived at by the High Court. Election petitions are tried by experienced

holdings.reasoning_summary: PW45 Sukhbir Singh false (no such truck union); tractor evidence vague, no reg no/hiring proof; bus owner not examined, PWs 30-32 unsatisfactory; defer to High Court.

holdings.text: Election expenses of respondent did not exceed prescribed limit; no proof of omitted expenses.

anchor.surface_text: Now coming to issue No. 8 which relates to the complaint of the appellant that the respondent, his agents and workers had hired several vehicles for conveyance of the voters to and from the polling

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vehicle expenses rejected earlier; food purchase witnesses not believed; documents unreliable; evidence not creditworthy.

holdings.text: Supreme Court generally accepts findings of fact by High Court in election petitions due to advantage of observing witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the High Court has correctly assessed, that evidence. Generally, this Court accepts the findings of fact arrived at by the High Court. Election petitions are tried by experienced

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court judges experienced, observed demeanour; great weight to their appreciation unless good reason to depart.

holdings.text: This appeal fails and the same is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All remaining issues (7,8,10) rejected; no corrupt practices proved.

anchor.surface_text: ,Carter and Anr. v. Mills 1 . Therein a pending election petition was allowed to be withdrawn on the dissolution of the Parliament. In doing so Coleridge, C.J. observed thus I am of opinion that this application should be granted. The Queen having been pleased to dissolve Parliament, of which fact the Court must take judicial companynizance, a case has arisen number expressly provided for in the Act and under these circumstances we must guide our proceedings by the old parliamentary practice on the subject. It is companymon knowledge, that according to the old practice the petition abated or dropped in such a case. We think the result is the same number, and that we therefore have authority, and ought to make an order for the return of the deposit.  1  9, Common Pleas p. 117.

precedents.cited_proposition: Pending election petition abates or drops on dissolution of Parliament, following old parliamentary practice
precedents.cited_holding: The Queen having been pleased to dissolve Parliament... the petition abated or dropped in such a case.

precedents.citation: Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh and Others 1  this Court proceeded on the basis that the dissolution of the assembly does number put an end to the election petition. For the reasons already mentioned we think that the High Court was right in its companyclusion that the election petition had number abated.
